9526b55a-11bb-45da-8733-d49e71add4a5.title: Digital Home System
9526b55a-11bb-45da-8733-d49e71add4a5.original_text: The System allows a web ready computer, cell phone or PDA to control a home's temperature, humidity, lights, security, and the state of small appliances. Users monitor and control home devices and systems. The system equipes with various environmental controllers and sensors. The sensor reads and saved value in the home database. The user read the temperature at a thermostat position. The user set the thermostat temperatures to between 60 ° F and 80 ° F, inclusive, at one degree increments. If a thermostat device allows a user to make a manual temperature setting, the setting remains in effect until the end of the planned or default time period, at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period. The system compatibles with a centralized HVAC (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning). The system adheres to the standards, policies and procedures of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers [ASHRAE 2010]. The user monitor and control a home’s humidity from any location, using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA. The user read the humidity at a humidistat position. The user sets the humidity level for a humidistat, from 30% to 60%, inclusive a 1% increments. The system uses wireless signals to communicate, through the master control unit, with the humidistats. The system consists of contact sensors and a set security alarms. The system manages up to fifty door and window contact sensors. The system activates both light and sound alarms one sound alarm and one light alarm subsystem, with multiple lights. The system provides information about the state of a power switch (OFF or ON), indicating the whether an appliance connected to the power switch is OFF or ON. The system changes the state of a power switch (OFF to ON, or ON to OFF), in turn changing the state of an appliance connected to the power switch. If a user changes the state of power switch device manually, the device remains in that state until the end of the planned or default time period, at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period. The system set various preset home parameters (temperature, humidity, security contacts, and on/off appliance/light status) for certain time periods. System provides a monthly planner. The user overrides planned parameter values, through the DH website, or if available, through manual switches on household devices. The system provides a report on the management and control of the home.

ai_result.snl_text:
**Actors Identified:**
- User (using web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA)
- System (includes master control unit, sensors, controllers)
- Thermostat Device
- Humidistat Device
- Power Switch Device

---

**Structured Natural Language (SNL) Requirements:**

1. The system shall provide the user with the ability to log in using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA.
2. The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the home’s temperature remotely.
3. The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the home’s humidity remotely.
4. The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected lights remotely.
5. The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected small appliances remotely.
6. The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state of all security contact sensors remotely.
7. The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the home’s temperature remotely.
8. The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the home’s humidity remotely.
9. The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the state (ON/OFF) of all connected lights remotely.
10. The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the state (ON/OFF) of all connected small appliances remotely.
11. The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the state of security alarms remotely.
12. The system shall provide the user with the ability to read the current temperature at each thermostat position.
13. The system shall provide the user with the ability to set the thermostat temperature between 60°F and 80°F, inclusive, at 1°F increments.
14. The system shall validate that any thermostat temperature set by the user is within the range of 60°F to 80°F, inclusive.
15. If the user attempts to set a thermostat temperature outside the valid range, then the system shall display an error message and reject the input.
16. The system shall provide the user with the ability to read the current humidity at each humidistat position.
17. The system shall provide the user with the ability to set the humidity level for a humidistat between 30% and 60%, inclusive, at 1% increments.
18. The system shall validate that any humidity value set by the user is within the range of 30% to 60%, inclusive.
19. If the user attempts to set a humidity value outside the valid range, then the system shall display an error message and reject the input.
20. The system shall be able to communicate with thermostats and humidistats using wireless signals through the master control unit.
21. The system shall be able to read temperature values from all connected thermostats.
22. The system shall be able to read humidity values from all connected humidistats.
23. The system shall be able to save all sensor readings in the home database.
24. The system shall be able to retrieve the latest sensor readings from the home database for display to the user.
25. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the state (ON/OFF) of each power switch.
26. The system shall provide the user with the ability to change the state of each power switch (ON to OFF or OFF to ON).
27. The system shall be able to update the state of the corresponding appliance when a power switch state is changed.
28. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the state (ON/OFF) of each connected appliance.
29. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the state (ON/OFF) of each connected light.
30. The system shall provide the user with the ability to change the state of each connected light (ON to OFF or OFF to ON).
31. The system shall be able to manage up to fifty door and window contact sensors.
32. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the status (open/closed) of each door and window contact sensor.
33. The system shall be able to activate the sound alarm subsystem.
34. The system shall be able to activate the light alarm subsystem.
35. The system shall be able to activate multiple lights in the light alarm subsystem.
36. The system shall be able to activate both the sound and light alarms simultaneously.
37. The system shall provide the user with the ability to set preset home parameters (temperature, humidity, security contacts, appliance/light status) for specific time periods.
38. The system shall provide the user with the ability to define planned time periods for parameter settings.
39. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view and edit the monthly planner.
40. The system shall be able to apply planned or default parameter settings at the beginning of each defined time period.
41. If a user overrides a planned parameter value through the DH website, then the system shall apply the user’s override for the remainder of the current time period.
42. If a user overrides a planned parameter value through a manual switch on a household device, then the system shall apply the user’s override for the remainder of the current time period.
43. If a user manually sets the thermostat temperature, then the thermostat device shall maintain the manual setting until the end of the planned or default time period.
44. At the end of the planned or default time period, the system shall revert the thermostat to the planned or default setting for the next time period.
45. If a user manually sets the power switch state, then the power switch device shall maintain the manual state until the end of the planned or default time period.
46. At the end of the planned or default time period, the system shall revert the power switch to the planned or default setting for the next time period.
47. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current planned and default parameter settings for all devices.
48. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current override status of all devices.
49. The system shall provide the user with the ability to clear an override and return a device to planned or default settings.
50. The system shall provide the user with the ability to generate a report on the management and control of the home.
51. The system shall be able to generate a report that includes temperature, humidity, security, and appliance/light status history.
52. The system shall provide the user with the ability to download or print the management and control report.
53. The system shall be able to notify the user if a sensor reading is outside of user-defined acceptable ranges.
54. The system shall be able to notify the user if a door or window contact sensor is triggered.
55. The system shall be able to notify the user if an alarm is activated.
56. The system shall provide the user with feedback confirming successful parameter changes.
57. The system shall provide the user with feedback if a parameter change fails, including the reason for failure.
58. The system shall ensure that all communications between user devices and the master control unit are secure.
59. The system shall log all user actions related to monitoring and controlling home devices.
60. The system shall log all system-initiated changes to device states.
61. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the activity log.
62. The system shall be compatible with a centralized HVAC system.
63. The system shall adhere to the standards, policies, and procedures of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE 2010).
64. The system shall provide the user with the ability to add new devices (thermostats, humidistats, sensors, switches, alarms) to the system.
65. The system shall provide the user with the ability to remove devices from the system.
66. The system shall validate that no more than fifty door and window contact sensors are configured at any time.
67. If the user attempts to add more than fifty contact sensors, then the system shall display an error and prevent the addition.
68. The system shall provide the user with the ability to assign names or locations to each device for identification.
69. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view a list of all configured devices and their current states.
70. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view device-specific details, including last communication time and battery status (if applicable).
71. The system shall provide the user with the ability to receive notifications via email or SMS for critical events (e.g., alarm activation, sensor breach).
72. The system shall provide the user with the ability to configure notification preferences for different event types.
73. The system shall provide the user with the ability to temporarily disable alarms for maintenance purposes.
74. The system shall provide the user with the ability to restore alarms after maintenance.
75. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current wireless signal strength for each device.
76. The system shall provide the user with the ability to test communication with any device from the user interface.
77. The system shall display an error message if communication with a device fails.
78. The system shall log all communication failures for troubleshooting.
79. The system shall provide the user with the ability to reset any device to factory settings.
80. The system shall require user confirmation before performing a factory reset on any device.

30. The system shall provide the user with the ability to change the state of each connected light (ON to OFF or OFF to ON).
31. The system shall be able to manage up to fifty door and window contact sensors.
32. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the status (open/closed) of each door and window contact sensor.
33. The system shall be able to activate the sound alarm subsystem.
34. The system shall be able to activate the light alarm subsystem.
35. The system shall be able to activate multiple lights in the light alarm subsystem.
36. The system shall be able to activate both the sound and light alarms simultaneously.
37. The system shall provide the user with the ability to set preset home parameters (temperature, humidity, security contacts, appliance/light status) for specific time periods.
38. The system shall provide the user with the ability to define planned time periods for parameter settings.
39. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view and edit the monthly planner.
40. The system shall be able to apply planned or default parameter settings at the beginning of each defined time period.
41. If a user overrides a planned parameter value through the DH website, then the system shall apply the user’s override for the remainder of the current time period.
42. If a user overrides a planned parameter value through a manual switch on a household device, then the system shall apply the user’s override for the remainder of the current time period.
43. If a user manually sets the thermostat temperature, then the thermostat device shall maintain the manual setting until the end of the planned or default time period.
44. At the end of the planned or default time period, the system shall revert the thermostat to the planned or default setting for the next time period.
45. If a user manually sets the power switch state, then the power switch device shall maintain the manual state until the end of the planned or default time period.
46. At the end of the planned or default time period, the system shall revert the power switch to the planned or default setting for the next time period.
47. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current planned and default parameter settings for all devices.
48. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current override status of all devices.
49. The system shall provide the user with the ability to clear an override and return a device to planned or default settings.
50. The system shall provide the user with the ability to generate a report on the management and control of the home.
51. The system shall be able to generate a report that includes temperature, humidity, security, and appliance/light status history.
52. The system shall provide the user with the ability to download or print the management and control report.
53. The system shall be able to notify the user if a sensor reading is outside of user-defined acceptable ranges.
54. The system shall be able to notify the user if a door or window contact sensor is triggered.
55. The system shall be able to notify the user if an alarm is activated.
56. The system shall provide the user with feedback confirming successful parameter changes.
57. The system shall provide the user with feedback if a parameter change fails, including the reason for failure.
58. The system shall ensure that all communications between user devices and the master control unit are secure.
59. The system shall log all user actions related to monitoring and controlling home devices.
60. The system shall log all system-initiated changes to device states.
61. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the activity log.
62. The system shall be compatible with a centralized HVAC system.
63. The system shall adhere to the standards, policies, and procedures of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE 2010).
64. The system shall provide the user with the ability to add new devices (thermostats, humidistats, sensors, switches, alarms) to the system.
65. The system shall provide the user with the ability to remove devices from the system.
66. The system shall validate that no more than fifty door and window contact sensors are configured at any time.
67. If the user attempts to add more than fifty contact sensors, then the system shall display an error and prevent the addition.
68. The system shall provide the user with the ability to assign names or locations to each device for identification.
69. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view a list of all configured devices and their current states.
70. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view device-specific details, including last communication time and battery status (if applicable).
71. The system shall provide the user with the ability to receive notifications via email or SMS for critical events (e.g., alarm activation, sensor breach).
72. The system shall provide the user with the ability to configure notification preferences for different event types.
73. The system shall provide the user with the ability to temporarily disable alarms for maintenance purposes.
74. The system shall provide the user with the ability to restore alarms after maintenance.
75. The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the current wireless signal strength for each device.
76. The system shall provide the user with the ability to test communication with any device from the user interface.
77. The system shall display an error message if communication with a device fails.
78. The system shall log all communication failures for troubleshooting.
79. The system shall provide the user with the ability to reset any device to factory settings.
80. The system shall require user confirmation before performing a factory reset on any device.

ai_requirements:
**Actors Identified:**
- User (using web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA)
- System (includes master control unit, sensors, controllers)
- Thermostat Device
- Humidistat Device
- Power Switch Device

---

**Structured Natural Language (SNL) Requirements:**

1.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to log in using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the home’s temperature remotely.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the home’s humidity remotely.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected lights remotely.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected small appliances remotely.

The system shall provide the user with the ability to read the current temperature at each thermostat position.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to set the thermostat temperature between 60°F and 80°F, inclusive, at 1°F increments.
The system shall validate that any thermostat temperature set by the user is within the range of 60°F to 80°F, inclusive.
If the user attempts to set a thermostat temperature outside the valid range, then the system shall display an error message and reject the input.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to read the current humidity at each humidistat position.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to set the humidity level for a humidistat between 30% and 60%, inclusive, at 1% increments.
The system shall validate that any humidity value set by the user is within the range of 30% to 60%, inclusive.
If the user attempts to set a humidity value outside the valid range, then the system shall display an error message and reject the input.
The system shall be able to communicate with thermostats and humidistats using wireless signals through the master control unit.
The system shall be able to read temperature values from all connected thermostats.
The system shall be able to read humidity values from all connected humidistats.
The system shall be able to save all sensor readings in the home database.
The system shall be able to retrieve the latest sensor readings from the home database for display to the user.
The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the state (ON/OFF) of each power switch.

items.requirement: The system equips with various environmental controllers and sensors.
items.reason: The AI requirements do not explicitly mention the system being equipped with a variety of environmental controllers and sensors as a general capability; they focus on specific devices.

items.requirement: The sensor reads and saved value in the home database.
items.reason: While the AI mentions saving sensor readings, it does not clearly state that the sensor itself is responsible for reading and saving the value in the database.

missing_in_ai.description: Requirements from original case study that AI failed to capture

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to log in using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA.
items.reason: The original requirements do not specify user authentication or login functionality; this is an implementation detail not present in the case study.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to generate a report on the management and control of the home.
items.reason: Reporting and exporting management/control history is not mentioned in the original case study and adds extra functionality.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to download or print the management and control report.
items.reason: Download/print features for reports are not specified in the original requirements and are additional details.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to add new devices (thermostats, humidistats, sensors, switches, alarms) to the system.
items.reason: Device addition/removal and related management are not described in the original requirements and represent extra system management features.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to assign names or locations to each device for identification.
items.reason: Naming or assigning locations to devices is not mentioned in the original case study and is an extra usability feature.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to view device-specific details, including last communication time and battery status (if applicable).
items.reason: Device-specific details like last communication time and battery status are not in the original requirements and are additional technical details.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to receive notifications via email or SMS for critical events (e.g., alarm activation, sensor breach).
items.reason: Notification delivery methods (email/SMS) and configuration are not specified in the original requirements.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to reset any device to factory settings.
items.reason: Factory reset functionality is not mentioned in the original requirements and is an implementation detail.

overspecified_in_ai.description: Requirements where AI was too detailed or specific beyond case study scope

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected lights remotely.
items.reason: The original requirements do not specify ON/OFF state monitoring for lights, only general control and monitoring.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to monitor the state (ON/OFF) of all connected small appliances remotely.
items.reason: The original requirements do not specify ON/OFF state monitoring for small appliances, only general control and monitoring.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to control the state of security alarms remotely.
items.reason: The original requirements mention activating alarms but do not specify remote control of alarm state by the user.

items.requirement: The system shall provide the user with the ability to view the state (ON/OFF) of each power switch.
items.reason: The original requirements do not mention power switches as a separate device type or their ON/OFF state.

incorrect_in_ai.description: Requirements where AI made factual errors or misinterpretations

detailed_ai_analysis.analysis_summary: The AI-generated requirements are generally comprehensive and capture most of the original case study's intent. However, the AI introduces several features not present in the original requirements, such as login, reporting, device management, and detailed device information, which may add unnecessary complexity. A few requirements are missing or not clearly mapped, such as the general presence of environmental controllers/sensors and the sensor's responsibility for saving data. There are also some logical mismatches where the AI assumes more granular control or monitoring than specified. Overall, the AI output is thorough but sometimes overreaches or misinterprets the original scope.
